page.title: 01THE BRENDON COUNTRYSIDE
page.content: In the north part of the Brendon Hills all the roads are very narrow and some places can only be reached by walking along ancient tracks with high hedges on each side. Close to Felons Oak 3 tracks cross and by climbing over any of the gates you can look over the fields and even see across the Bristol Channel to Wales. Most of the fields are cultivated and the red earth shows up in all the green. There are clumps of deciduous trees scattered along the edges of the lanes. Sheep can be seen in the odd patches of rough pasture, and the farm buildings look small from so high. The hedges are overgrown and are full of wildlife. In June there are many wild flowers, birds, stag beetles, butterflies and other insects. Few people live here so the wildlife seems very abundant.
